{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3599841,"name":"Nobre ","username":"nobre_coding","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/edb3f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T13:30:09.937Z","cooked":"

Hey FRC community,

My name is Nobre. I’m a former FIRST LEGO League competitor and currently a mentor for FIRST teams in Brazil. Over the past few months, I’ve been developing a tool called PathPlanner SPIKE, which adapts the motion planning concepts of the FRC PathPlanner to the SPIKE Prime platform used in FLL.

The motivation behind this project is to offer FLL teams access to advanced trajectory generation tools, reducing their dependence on trial-and-error code and making it easier to build smooth, consistent autonomous routines. Just like PathPlanner has empowered FRC teams to fine-tune their paths and optimize autonomous modes, this tool brings similar functionality to the FLL context. It allows teams to visually design paths, automatically generate Python code with a custom control library tailored to SPIKE Prime, and execute the trajectory accurately on the competition field.

So why am I bringing this to the FRC community?

Because you all know motion planning better than anyone. Your feedback could help improve the project significantly — especially in areas like trajectory following (I’m currently implementing and testing Pure Pursuit), backend structure for future extensions, and ideas for building a more user-friendly interface for path creation, perhaps inspired by the PathPlanner GUI many of you are familiar with.

My goals going forward include expanding support for SPIKE sensors, adapting to different FLL strategies, enhancing the UI, and fully documenting the project to make it easy for others to contribute.

The tool is still in its early stages, but it’s already usable and open-source. You can check it out here: GitHub - meuNobre/Path-Planner-FRC-for-FLL: Adaptation of the FRC Path Planner for FLL The focus of this project is to recreate the application used in the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) for trajectory creation, adapting it for the FIRST LEGO League (FLL). This allows teams to program their robots without needing direct physical access to the competition table.

If you’re interested in the project, have suggestions, or would like to collaborate in any way — whether through code, design, testing, or sharing ideas — I’d be happy to connect. Feel free to reply here, email me at nobrecoding@gmail.com.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts and building something great together.

Also, I look forward to finding a collaborator for the project, good Day!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T15:23:25.951Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":421,"readers_count":420,"score":129.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500137,"topic_slug":"bringing-frc-pathplanner-concepts-to-spike-prime-help-me-improve-motion-planning-for-fll","display_username":"Nobre ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75365,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST Competitor and Mentor "},"post_url":"/t/bringing-frc-pathplanner-concepts-to-spike-prime-help-me-improve-motion-planning-for-fll/500137/2","custom_user_title":"FIRST Competitor and Mentor ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600165,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T16:47:36.747Z","cooked":"

The current meta in FRC for differential drive pose feedback control is LTVUnicycleController (WPILib API 2025.3.2) feeding velocity commands to two wheel velocity P controllers. Pure pursuit has a lot of theoretical and practical downsides I’ve talked about before here.

There’s even better-performing controllers like LTVDifferentialDriveController (WPILib API 2025.3.2), but they require physical modeling that’s likely too difficult for an elementary schooler. Furthermore, LTVUnicycleController and LTVDifferentialDriveController are nontrivial to implement. Here’s an LQR implementation in Python in case that’s a road you want to go down:

import numpy as np
import scipy as sp


def lqr(A, B, Q, R):
    P = sp.linalg.solve_discrete_are(A, B, Q, R)
    return np.linalg.solve(B.T @ P @ B + R, B.T @ P @ A)

Alternatively, RobotPy has Python wrappers for all of WPILib’s stuff, but idk how difficult that is to leverage for your project.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T17:33:12.974Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":96.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500137,"topic_slug":"bringing-frc-pathplanner-concepts-to-spike-prime-help-me-improve-motion-planning-for-fll","display_username":"6894 Lead prog/driver","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6894 | Lead prog/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/bringing-frc-pathplanner-concepts-to-spike-prime-help-me-improve-motion-planning-for-fll/500137/4","custom_user_title":"6894 | Lead prog/Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600561,"name":"Nobre ","username":"nobre_coding","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/edb3f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T20:45:29.362Z","cooked":"

For an FLL robot, I believe that Pure Pursuit is already more than sufficient in terms of accuracy and performance — especially considering the table size, type of challenges, and hardware limitations.

Unfortunately, it’s not possible to directly reuse WPILib in the SPIKE Prime environment, since it’s a closed system with limited processing power and library compatibility. That’s why I’m currently exploring the possibility of expanding the project to also support Pybricks, which offers much more freedom and could potentially allow the integration of more robust concepts like LQR, with some level of optimization.

If you’re interested in contributing in any way, I’m available — just send me an email at nobrecoding@gmail.com.

Mochatitan:

Id love to try to help if you need

That’s awesome — thank you so much!
I’d definitely love your help! Right now I’m in the process of improving the path smoothing logic and expanding compatibility to other platforms like Pybricks.

If you’re interested in getting involved, feel free to reach out via email at nobrecoding@gmail.com or Discord “nobre_dos_codigos”— I can share more about the current code structure and what kind of contributions would be helpful.

Looking forward to collaborating!

nobre_coding:

it’s a closed system with limited processing power

After looking into this further, I think you may be locked out of most modern features no matter which language you choose or how much optimization you do. The roboRIO 2.0 with its 866 MHz dual-core ARM Cortex-A9 CPU struggles to run FRC’s state-of-the-art features in Java and Python, and the SPIKE Prime only has a 100 MHz ARM Cortex-M4 CPU according to its datasheet.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T21:37:00.064Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":279,"readers_count":278,"score":75.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500137,"topic_slug":"bringing-frc-pathplanner-concepts-to-spike-prime-help-me-improve-motion-planning-for-fll","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://assets.education.lego.com/v3/assets/blt293eea581807678a/bltf512a371e82f6420/5f8801baf4f4cf0fa39d2feb/techspecs_techniclargehub.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/bringing-frc-pathplanner-concepts-to-spike-prime-help-me-improve-motion-planning-for-fll/500137/7","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600652,"name":"Nobre ","username":"nobre_coding","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/edb3f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T22:06:12.969Z","cooked":"

You’re absolutely right — the SPIKE Prime’s hardware is very limited, and I completely agree that running complex FRC-grade motion planning systems like LTV controllers or full-blown LQR isn’t realistic.

But just to clarify: my goal isn’t to replicate the full capabilities of modern FRC motion planning. What I’m aiming to do is build a simplified version — a “mini PathPlanner” — that works well within the constraints of FLL.

Pure Pursuit, basic smoothing, and a simple PID control layer are more than enough for the scale of the game table and the type of challenges we face in FLL. My goal is practicality: to save time, improve reliability, and help teams avoid tedious trial-and-error path tuning.

Also, part of my focus right now is to study all these motion planning approaches and choose the best platform to implement them. Currently, I’m developing the tool as a web-based prototype, but my long-term goal is to transform it into a standalone app, similar to the official FRC PathPlanner, with a better interface and more features.

I really appreciate your insights and technical feedback — it helps me stay grounded on what makes sense for the platform!
